title: Fundamentals in Artificial Intelligence
requirements: For students in MSc Artificial Intelligence; Not For students who have taken CSCI5150 or ELEG5760 or CSCI3320 or CSCI3230
description: With Artificial Intelligence widely employed across various domains, it is essential to learn the basics of AI and get to know different sub-areas of AI. This course will cover the basics and techniques of artificial intelligence, as well as the introduction, general research landscape and frontier of each sub-field in artificial intelligence. This course covers the following topics: Search: uninformed search, informed search and multi-agent search. Machine learning techniques, including linear regression, logistic regression, decision trees, random forests, Bayesian networks, inference and sampling, hidden Markov models and particle filtering; K-nearest neighbors, K-means, support vector machines, gradient boosting. Neural networks and optimization. Introduction to computer vision and natural language processing. Reinforcement learning and recommendation systems. Generative models.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:1. Understand the basic concepts in artificial intelligence 2. Understand the principles of various machine learning and deep learning techniques3.Understand the principles of different types of neural networks and their optimization4. Understand the principles of reinforcement learning algorithm and recommendation systems5. Apply and evaluate the AI techniques to solve real world problems
syllabus: This course covers the fundamentals: Search: uninformed search, informed search and multi-agent search. Machine learning techniques, including linear regression, logistic regression, decision trees, random forests, Bayesian networks, inference and sampling, hidden Markov models and particle filtering; K-nearest neighbors, K-means, support vector machines, gradient boosting, neural networks, and optimization. Introduction to computer vision and natural language processing. Reinforcement learning and recommendation systems. Generative models.Teaching PlanWeeks    Course Topics1    Introduction, Logic, Reasoning and Learning2    Search: Uninformed search, Informed search, Searching with other agents3    Machine Learning: Linear Regression, Logistic Regression, Decision Trees, Random Forests 4    Machine Learning: Bayesian networks, Inference and Sampling5    Machine Learning: Hidden Markov Models and Particle Filtering6    Machine Learning: K-Nearest Neighbors, K-Means, Support Vector Machines, Gradient Boosting7    Machine Learning: Neural Networks8    Optimization: Backpropagation and Stochastic Gradient Descent 9    Introduction to Computer Vision10    Introduction to Natural Language Processing11    Reinforcement Learning, Recommendation Systems12    Generative Models

Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach (3rd ed.), Englewood Cliffs: Prentice hall, 2010.2.    Mehryar Mohri, Afshin Rostamizadeh and Ameet Talwalkar, Foundations of Machine Learning (Adaptive Computation and Machine Learning series) 2nd Edition, The MIT Press, December 2018.3.     Ian Goodfellow, Yoshua Bengio, and Aaron Courville, Deep Learning (Adaptive Computation and Machine Learning series), The MIT Press, November 2016.4.    Pytorch tutorial: https://pytorch.org/tutorials/beginner/basics/intro.html5.    Deep Learning book: https://www.deeplearningbook.org/6.    Machine Learning book: https://ai.stanford.edu/~nilsson/MLBOOK.pdf

title: Artificial Intelligence in Practice
requirements: For students in MSc Artificial Intelligence
description: With the fast development of artificial intelligence, it is critical to understand how to build an AI system tailored for specific tasks. This course will teach you the general programming and designing practices of AI systems, understanding how to build a neural network, how to collect training data, and how to design a successful AI project.This course covers the principles of machine learning, data preparation and loading, basic vector operations, multi-layer perception, convolutional neural networks, sequential prediction, vision recognition, text recognition, model optimization and deployment, and distributed training.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:1. Understand how to design an AI system for a specific task, including data preparation, model selection, model training, and model deployment;2. Develop the programming skills for vector operations and construction of different network structures, including multi-layer perceptron, convolutional neural networks, and recurrent neural networks;3. Develop the programming skills for data preparation, data loading, parallelism and optimization, parallel training, and distributed training;4. Develop the system design skills to build an AI project, including housing price prediction, visual classification, and text analysis;5. Design an AI application using the pretrained large foundational models, including stable diffusion-based image generation, large language models, and image segmentation.
syllabus: 1. Basic vector, matrix, and tensor operations;2. Image, audio, text, video, and sequential data representation;3. Network structures, multi-layer perception, convolutional neural networks, and recurrent neural network;4. Data preparation, data loading parallelism and optimization, parallel training, distributed training;5. Model optimization and on-device deployment; Large foundation models, stable diffusion-based image generation, large language model, image segmentation;6. Deep learning practices, housing price prediction, visual classification, text analysisTeaching PlanWeeks    Course Topics1    Introduction, logistics, a simple machine learning example.2    Basic vector, matrix, and tensor operations. Introduction to Numpy library.3    1D and 2D signals. Image, audio, text, video, and sequential data representation. Introduction to Scipy, matplotlib and Pytorch.4    Network structure, multi-layer perception, convolutional neural networks, and recurrent neural network.5    Deep learning practice: housing price prediction (Boston House Dataset)6    Data preparation and data loading optimization7    Deep learning practice: visual classification (Fashion MNIST dataset)8    Parallel training, data parallelism, multi-GPU training, distributed training.9    Deep learning practice: text analysis (sentiment analysis on an IMDB dataset)10    Model optimization and on-device deployment.11    Usage of large foundation models: stable diffusion-based image generation, large language model, image segmentation.12    Project presentation and summary
required_readings: There is no textbook that can satisfy the needs of this course. The course contents will be organized in the form of lecture notes, as well as a list of recommended readings.
recommended_readings: 1. Pytorch tutorial: https://pytorch.org/tutorials/beginner/basics/intro.html2. Tensorflow tutorial: https://www.tensorflow.org/tutorials3. Numpy tutorial: https://numpy.org/doc/stable/user/absolute_beginners.html

title: Emerging Technologies in Artificial Intelligence
requirements: For students in MSc Artificial Intelligence;Pre-requisites: AIMS5701 and AIMS5702
description: This course introduces emerging and enabling technologies in artificial intelligence to solve real-world problems in a various daily and industrial application. The course will offer a number of research or topical seminars, given by research or industry experts, to let the students keep abreast of the trends of the development in artificial intelligence technologies. title: Deep Learning Fundamentals and Theories
requirements: For students in MSc Artificial Intelligence; Not for students who have taken ELEG5491 or ELEG5760 or CMSC5743 or AIST4010
description: This course provides an introduction to deep learning. Students taking this course will learn the basics, theories, models, algorithms, implementation, and recent progress of deep learning, and obtain empirical experience on the designing, training, and understanding of deep neural networks. The course starts by establishing the relations between classical machine learning models and deep learning models, followed by the introduction of representative neural network architectures, optimization techniques for training deep neural networks, implementation of large-scale deep learning, multi-task deep learning, transferred deep learning, recurrent neural networks, transformer networks, applications of deep learning to language processing and computer vision, and understanding why deep learning works. The students taking are expected to have basic background knowledge on calculus, linear algebra, probability, statistics, and random process as a prerequisite.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:1. Understand the fundamental concepts, theories and algorithms of deep learning. 2. Understand the relations between conventional machine learning models and deep learning models.3. Understand the principles of designing different deep neural networks for various applications.4. Implement and train deep neural networks with deep learning toolboxes.Understand why deep learning outperforms other machine learning methods when the training data is in large scale.5. Obtain empirical experience of designing and training deep models in practical applications.

title: Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition
requirements: For students in MSc Artificial Intelligence; Not for students who have taken ENGG5104 or CMSC5711 or CSCI5280 or MAEG5720
description: Computer vision enables computers and systems to derive high-level understanding from digital images, videos and other visual inputs.This course will cover fundamental knowledge and advanced topics in image processing, computer vision and pattern recognition, including image acquisition, processing and transformations, feature detection, segmentation, motion estimation, stereo vision, 3D reconstruction and modeling, scene detection and classification, object alignment and tracking, face detection and recognition, color image processing and digital photography. Machine learning and deep learning algorithms for computer vision and their system applications will be discussed.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:1. Understand how mathematical and scientific concepts are applied in image processing and computer vision2. Understand how to extract information and features such as point, lines, corners and colour information from images3. Understand the process of retrieving 3-D shapes and motions from image data and the methods of object tracking 4. Perform image transformation in the color and spatial domains 5. Understand basic knowledge and algorithms in computer vision6.  Identify, formulate and develop practical and innovative image processing and computer vision applications to solve real world problems.
syllabus: This course will cover fundamental knowledge and advanced topics in image processing, computer vision and pattern recognition, including image acquisition, processing and transformations, feature detection, segmentation, motion estimation, stereo vision, 3D reconstruction and modeling, scene detection and classification, object alignment and tracking, face detection and recognition, color image processing and digital photography. title: Natural Language Processing
requirements: For students in MSc Artificial Intelligence;Not for students who have taken CSCI5640
description: Natural language processing (NLP) focuses on system development that allows human-computer interaction using linguistic and textual data. This course introduces the main concepts of the natural language processing tasks, such as parsers, syntax, semantics, discourse, language modeling, machine translation, text generation and summarization, multilinguality and multimodality, etc. It also covers the research methods, including statistical and stochastic learning methods, expectation maximization algorithms and deep learning models. It will further discuss the applications and technological advances in large language models.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:1. Understand the role of NLP in human computer interaction using linguistic and textual data2. Understand the textural information processing techniques to meet real-world needs 3. Understand the set of key machine learning and statistical methods which are widely used in NLP4. Understand the applications and technological advances in language models5. Implement practical applications of NLP using common tools such as NLTK, Pytorch and Dynet
syllabus: This course introduces the main concepts of the natural language processing tasks, such as parsers, syntax, semantics, discourse, language modeling, machine translation, text generation and summarization, multilinguality and multimodality, etc. It also covers the research methods, including statistical and stochastic learning methods, expectation maximization algorithms and deep learning models. It will further discuss the applications and technological advances in large language models.Weeks    Course Topics1    Introduction to NLP 2    Text Classification, logistic regression, parsing3    Syntax, semantics, word vectors and vector semantics4    Statistical and stochastic learning methods: hidden Markov models, trees, conditional random fields, 5    N-gram models, expectation maximization algorithms, latent variable models6    Language modeling, RNN, attention, transformer, BERT, GPT7    Computational graphs and sequence-to-sequence models8    Pretrained language models, fine-tuning and prompting9    Text generation and summarization10    Multilinguality and multimodality11    NLP system applications: question answering, conversational systems, ChatGPT12    Advances in large language models

title: Generative Artificial Intelligence
requirements: For students in MSc Artificial Intelligence;Not for students who have taken AIST5030 or SEEM5030
description: Generative models are widely used in different applications of artificial intelligence. This course covers mathematical and computational foundations of generative modeling, as well as applications in engineering, design, science, and the arts. The topics include foundation models, deep learning models, variational autoencoders, generative adversarial networks, autoregressive models such as Transformers, neural text decoding, prompt programming, and detection of generated content. Applications to language models and multimodality system, as well as social responsibility in generative modeling will also be discussed.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:1. Understand the concepts underlying generative AI2. Understand the principles of various generative AI models and applications3. Develop the practical skills to design and implement generative models to various domains 4. Develop the awareness of ethical and social responsibility associated with generative AI
syllabus: Teaching PlanWeeks    Course Topics1    Introduction to generative AI2    Deep learning models 3    Autoregressive models, sequence-to-sequence model4    Variational autoencoders5    Generative adversarial networks6    Flow-based models, diffusion models7    Language models and prompt engineering, neural text decoding, detection of generated content8    Chat-GPT and conversational AI9    Speech, audio, music generation10    Image and video generation11    Generative AI for non-engineering applications12    Ethical and social implications

title: Technology Commercialization of AI Innovations
requirements:
For students in MSc Artificial Intelligence; or
For all MSc Programmes in Faculty of Engineering;Pre-requisites: AIMS5701 and AIMS5702;Exclusion: CMSC5730 or ENGG3802/3803/5700 or ESTR3502 or FTEC5570 or IEMS5712 or SEEM3450 or IERG5340 or ROSE5790
description: Artificial Intelligence has brought significant impact on all facets of human activities, including personal, industrial, and societal. This course aims at challenging the students to unleash their innovative power to create new AI applications and services that may lead to the formation of new startups in the Great Bay Area. The course will introduce a market-oriented model of thinking to complement the technology-oriented model, thus enabling the students to develop an all-rounded thinking pattern and get prepared to join the commercial world.The course adopts the Lean Start-Up Approach to Entrepreneurship to guide the students to go through a rigorous business development process, consisting of the following steps.1. Define their business idea.2. Design their products or services.3. Develop their Minimal Viable Products (MVP) to illustrate their designs.4. Devise their business strategies to reach their target markets.5. Develop the business plan to explain their ideas clearly.This is a highly interactive and hands-on to help project teams to refine their business plans. The students should have the knowledge in machine learning and deep learning.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:1.    Develop a market-oriented model of thinking that will complement their familiar technology-oriented model of thinking in order to better prepare them for entering into the commercial world.2.    Unleash their innovative power to develop one or more marketable applications (products or services) based on the AI technologies they learned.3.    Develop execution plans for these potential products/services based on the Lean Start-Up Approach.4.    Produce slide decks to introduce viable business models for these products/services.5.    Potentially, form one or more business development team(s) and create real opportunities to launch startups in HKSTP or other incubators in the Great Bay Area.
syllabus: (Week 1) Lecture 1: Technology Commercialization – Introduce the Lean Start Up Approach.(Week 2) Lecture 2: Lean Canvas – How shall you create a business idea?(Week 3) Discussion 1: What is your business idea?(Week 4) Lecture 3: Market Opportunities – Where is your target market?(Week 5) Lecture 4: Business Models – How shall you structure your business?(Week 6) Discussion 2: What do you really want to sell?(Week 7) Lecture 5: Minimal Viable Product (MVP) – What shall you build?(Week 8) Discussion 3: How to build your MVP?(Week 9) Lecture 6: Team Formation – Who will you need to work with?(Week 10) Lecture 7: Business Plan – How can you develop a viable business plan to get investors’ interests?(Week 11) Discussion 4: How to make your business plan?(Week 12) Project Presentation

URL: https://shabablab.com/blog/article/design-thinking-entrepreneurship/#:~:text=The%20design%20thinking%20process%20requires,very%20iterative%20instead%20of%20sequential.4.    Minimal Viable Product: A Step-to-Step Guide. title: From Business Plan to Investable AI Ventures
requirements:
For students in MSc Artificial Intelligence; or 
For all MSc Programmes in Faculty of Engineering;Pre-requisite: AIMS5760 or IEMS5712 or IERG5340;A team with AI application ideas for commercialization in mind
description: The course offers a unique blend of theory and practical application in transforming business ideas in artificial intelligence (AI) innovations into investable ventures, through holistic experiential learning experience. It empowers students with the strategies and communication skills needed to create compelling investment proposals, to convey their vision, articulate the unique value proposition of their AI solutions, and demonstrate their understanding of market dynamics and competitive landscape. The students will learn the design thinking business remodeling approach and the efficient fundraising strategies to prepare for the compelling investment pitches and formalizing plans to attract funding. The course offers real-world pitching opportunities for the students to pitch their business plans persuasively to the genuine investors in the market, gaining experience that goes beyond traditional academic assessments.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:1.    Create viable investment proposals for AI-based business ventures.2.    Understand and apply principles of design thinking for AI applications in business model ideation.3.    Understand the key considerations and challenges in transforming a business plan into a viable venture.4.    Analyze and develop corporate strategies in different patent situations.5.    Understand and apply effective fundraising strategies.6.    Develop and present persuasive pitches to prospective investors and venture capitalists.

title: Artificial Intelligence Internship
requirements: For students in MSc Artificial Intelligence
description: This course is designed to allow students to acquire a basic understanding and the skills of the practical aspects of the artificial intelligence area. During the internship, the student must attach to a company in a study-related position for no less than 12 weeks. The student will have an academic supervisor (as primary supervisor) and an industry co-supervisor from the company, both have the expertise to provide advice to the student. The student must submit a report summarizing the internship experience at the end of the internship. Additional presentation may be required by the hosting company.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:1.    Understand the impact of artificial intelligence in a global and societal context。2.    Use the techniques, skills, and modern engineering tools necessary for engineering practice appropriate to the degree discipline.
